I wonder, maybe can we delay the sending of the message, until the preview is generated? So the user taps on Send, but the message is actually sent a couple of milliseconds later, with the link preview?

This is part of the design. We don’t ever want to send a link preview the user hasn’t had a chance to see and approve. Sometimes link previews can get generated from undesirable things / provide content that you don’t want in your message so we give the user an opportunity to remove it. posts.cooked:
This isn’t a UX/UI issue but a feature issue that leads to UX issues, which is why I am putting it under the feature requests.

Currently the method for embedding something when sending a link is to type the link, wait a few seconds for the embed to fully load, then send. Even then, it’s not guaranteed to start the embed process. It’s very glitchy and confusing, a lot of people don’t understand this mechanism because it goes against every other app that does embeds, and they send the link immediately, thinking the embed will load but it won’t.

I was thinking that maybe there was a way to fix this problem which is especially present on slow internet connections where loading the embed takes a while:

If a user sends a message with a link and the embed hasn’t loaded, then the sender client should still try loading the embed in the background (with a timeout, say 30 seconds). If it succeeds, then it sends another (invisible) message telling the other clients to update the first message with the new embed data that the sender client just generated. Kind of like the mechanism used for editing messages but instead you add embeds.

This way, embeds could still load for messages without the sender having to wait for the embed to fully load every time before sending a message. No one likes to wait.
This isn’t a solution but if you send a link but forget to wait for the embed, edit the message and it’ll get the embed again.
If you type a link that has not yet loaded the preview and schedule the send, does the preview have a chance to load or is it locked as though you simply sent the message?

https://community.signalusers.org/t/load-link-embeds-after-sending-message/59083/2?u=hackerbirds

That’s good to know but yes, not a solution. The big problem here is having to wait and not being able to just send instantly.

https://community.signalusers.org/t/load-link-embeds-after-sending-message/59083/3?u=hackerbirds

I tried that and it seems that once the message is scheduled, it won’t load any preview after that. That should also be fixed ideally.

If my proposed solution works as intended, this should be rather straightforward to implement. They’ve already done most of the work with message editing, and backwards compatibility isn’t even necessary, strictly speaking. Old clients that don’t support the feature could just silently drop the unknown message proto and not see an embed, which is just how it is right now anyway. I really hope to see that feature someday, I’ve seen so many people confused by how embeds/preview work.

posts.cooked:
I could have sworn I made a post about this before, and I just recently had some more thoughts on this that I wanted to share. However, it seems like the post was deleted for some unknown reason.

I’ll rewrite (basically) what my old post said, at least what I can remember from it since I don’t have access to it anymore. Then, I’ll talk about some of my new thoughts on this problem.

Embed links in other apps are generated after sending a message. This works completely differently from how they are done on Signal. On Signal, you must wait 2 - 5 seconds (I tested this) for your embed to load before sending your message, otherwise it will be sent without an embed.

The only way to correct this is to edit the message, make a small change like adding a space, then remove it. This is very tedious and annoying, but it doesn’t have to be like this!

This can be improved. Since Signal embeds are seemingly done by the sender and sent as part of the message content, so we cannot easily add this afterwards.

Signal could make a change where the receiver generates the embed based on the content of the URL, however this could be dangerous. Now, you have a way to force the receiving client to load whatever URL you want. This gives the sender a way to grab the IP address of the receiver by directing them to a website they control. This could also lead to even worse attacks if the code Signal is using to grab the webpage content is exploitable. So, clearly we can’t do that.

However, there are some good ways to correct this. A very simple way to mitigate the problem would be counting an embed as a “change” to the message, allowing the user to edit the message and hit send as soon as the embed loads. This would still be tedious, but would be a little less tedious as you wouldn’t need the step of adding and removing a space to your message. An even better solution would be to automate this. If you send a message with a link before the embed can be generated, Signal will wait for the embed data to be ready, then can automatically edit your message. This approach would completely fix the issue without any security concerns as it would be done by the sending client.

I wanted to talk about this because this problem keeps happening repeatedly to me. I have convinced many people to switch to Signal, but not all of them are “tech savvy”. They don’t know they have to wait for a link preview to embed before sending it, they don’t even know what an “embed” is. I’ve tried explaining this to some of them, but not all of them understand it. Also, since most other messaging apps allow you to just send a link and have it embed afterwards, they might just assume Signal will “get to it” eventually or that it’s just being slow. They don’t understand how the Signal protocol works, and they shouldn’t have to according to Signal’s Development Ideology. The reason Signal can’t easily embed a link preview retroactively is because of all the security built into the protocol. The receiving client can’t generate it after because that would be insecure, the server can’t generate it because it can’t decrypt the message, etc. This is good, but it’s an example of security getting in the way of being easy to use. It’s not a huge deal, but this can be corrected by implementing my suggested fix.

I think it was mentioned in this thread, but if the idea behind embeds needing to be confirmed by the user is based on security+privacy motivations, why not add a pop-up if a link is sent before the embed has loaded? Something like,

One of your links doesn’t have a preview yet. Do you want to send without it?

  • Yes
  • No
  • Don’t ask again

I don’t think it’s too much of a “new option,” just a little warning that sending earlier will make it so that the message does not have a preview at all.

posts.cooked: I feel (and this does not mean your idea is invalid, just a personal opinion) that this would lead to bad UX. I supposed that a second toggle where disabling link previews to always remind to embed that is opt-in would work, but this wouldn’t help non-techsavy people either, unless you tell the person to change that setting (which is only a band-aid to the problem, that could work nonetheless)

I appreciate the non-personal disclosure! No worries though, I’m well aware we’re just having a conversation born out of our mutual desire to make Signal an even stronger contender against the corporate behemoths so commonly patronized out there.

As for your idea, I’m confused by what you mean when it comes to “second toggle.” If you’re referring to having users be able to set whether this pop-up appears in the future, that was my intent with the checkbox; my idea would be that, when this check box is (eventually) set, that is, when a user understands the logic intuitively, it would disappear on a Yes/No response with a little hovered text box (similar to the “we’ll remind you in X days” reminders for when you just created your account so you remember your PIN), saying “If you change your mind, you can bring up the option in Settings.”

And then, I suppose, when the embed actually loads, there could be a little (x) in the corner of the embed to remove it deliberately.

posts.name: Delamcode
posts.cooked:
Sorry for not being clear,
Because a user would likely get annoyed at a random pop up every time they try to send a link (assuming this issue happens often), it is probably better for UX to be an option that is opt-in in settings, but then this issue will continue to happen, unless you tell your contacts to please enable that setting.
But I’m not a UX designer so…

Ohhh okay I see what you’re saying!

Yes, it would definitely be annoying to have that pop-up come up every time; that’s precisely why the “do not show again” button would be front and center. I don’t think the solution is for it to be opt-in, as the whole point of the pop-up is to interrupt a premature send so that a user understands that their URL preview won’t be loaded if they send before it’s ready.

I get the general sentiment for everything to be opt-in, but in some cases opt-out is actually exactly the functionality we’re looking for, that is, “hey, we’re gonna nag you real quick because you’re about to do something that you might then think is a bug, when in reality is intended. You cool on how this works now? Okay, sick, tap that checkmark to never be reminded again, since now we’ve got this reminder in the bag.” It’s kinda like how some email clients will show a pop-up before you send if you said the word “attached,” but it detected no attachment. It’s a slight annoyance the first time in the pursuit of better understanding for how the program works!
